message_1: What is the nuclear decay mode of a carbon-14 atom and what element is formed after the decay process?
message_2:
Carbon-14 undergoes beta-minus decay (β- decay), which is a type of radioactive decay where a neutron in the nucleus is converted into a proton, and an electron (called a beta particle) is emitted. In this process, an antineutrino is also released.

When carbon-14 decays, it transforms into nitrogen-14, as the atomic number (number of protons) increases by one while the mass number (sum of protons and neutrons) remains the same. The decay equation can be written as:

¹⁴C → ¹⁴N + β⁻ + ν̅

where ¹⁴C is carbon-14, ¹⁴N is nitrogen-14, β⁻ is the emitted beta particle (electron), and ν̅ is the antineutrino.
